Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer applied the correct legal standard of proof in assessing the immigration application
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant's work experience documentation and testimony
Legal_Rule: The standard of proof for permanent residence applications in Canada is balance of probabilities, not beyond a reasonable doubt
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, depending on context
Procedural_Issue: Misapplication of the legal standard by the visa officer
Grounds_for_Claim: Material error of law due to incorrect standard of proof
Review_Standard: Correctness, as it involves an error of law
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Found lacking due to incorrect legal standard applied
Key_Evidence_Considered: Work experience claims, application documents, cross-examination transcript
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Canadian administrative law
Applicant_Challenge: Denial of application based on overly strict standard of proof
Legal_Rule_Source: Statutory interpretation and case law on standard of proof in immigration decisions
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination by a different visa officer
Legal_Provision: Sections of IRPA relating to permanent residence eligibility and procedural fairness
Legal_Provision_Cited: Implied: Sections of IRPA and principles from Canadian administrative law
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Insufficient proof of work experience under incorrect standard
Applicable_Process: Immigration application process followed by judicial review
Governing_Rule: Balance of probabilities standard in immigration assessments
